author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Author talks, signs new cookbook
text:
Author talks, signs new cookbook Oct 22, 2015 Enlarge... 
Rockland — Malia Dell will talk about what it was like to spend the last four years writing her newly released cookbook Thursday, Nov. 5, at 6 p.m. at Rockland Public Library, 80 Union St. She also will share tips on how to eat more healthful, homemade workday meals … and offer samples. 
“Food That Works: Real Meals to Survive the 9 to 5” is a cookbook for busy people who want access to homemade meals, Monday through Friday. This weekly food system features shopping lists, prep work and easy recipes with minimal cleanup. This approach turns one’s fridge into the ultimate grab-n-go, stocked with nutritious whole foods ready to assemble on the fly. The aims to prove that healthy homemade meals are attainable. 
Dell is a certified wellness consultant whose mission is to improve workplace health. She helps clients increase their productivity, gain control of their eating habits and develop their confidence in the kitchen. Working with corporations, universities and other organizations, Dell educates in a way that is both inspiring and entertaining. She also is a fitness instructor, self-taught cook and advocate for ending food waste. 
Books will be available for purchase and signing after the presentation, which is sponsored by Friends of the Rockland Library. It is free and open to the public. For more information, call 594-0310. 
Courier Publications’ A&E Editor Dagney C. Ernest can be reached at (207) 594-4401, ext. 115; or dernest@courierpublicationsllc.com.
